thread.title: Loved-up couple with 35 year age gap often mistaken for DAD and DAUGHTER
thread.title_full: Loved-up couple with 35 year age gap often mistaken for DAD and DAUGHTER

author: Erin Cardiff
title: Loved-up couple with 35 year age gap often mistaken for DAD and DAUGHTER
text:
Michelle and Kenny Micklewright (Photo: PA Real Life) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A woman married to a man 35 years older than her says he is often mistaken for her DAD. 
Michelle Micklewright first met Kenny Micklewright when she was 18 and he was 53. 
And even though Kenny, now 64, was older than both her parents, Michelle said she'd always had a teenage crush on him. 
Yet despite their rather large age gap, the pair have since married and had a daughter, nine-year-old Tyanna 
Michelle, now 29, fell pregnant just three months after they became an item – at the tender age of 18. 
Now, she even says that, out the two of them, Kenny is the youngest at heart, as he loves partying while she prefers a quiet night in. 
“I’d known Kenny for a year before anything happened. I didn’t think much of it at first, but once I got speaking to him, I really fell for him,” said Michelle of Middlesbrough, North Yorkshire. Michelle first met Kenny when she was 18 and he was 53 (Photo: PA Real Life) 
“He’s really funny and doesn’t act his age at all. 
“My teenage crush all those years ago is now my husband. He might be an older model but I wouldn’t trade him in for the world.” 
Michelle and Kenny’s generation-spanning romance began back in 2006, when they met at the pub he managed. Read More 'I got down on my knees and prayed to God': Ex-porn star becomes born-again Christian after car crash 
With only a small handful of boyfriends to date, she wasn’t looking for anything serious. 
But, over the next year, she gradually began to fall for Kenny - charmed by his sense of humour and bubbly personality. 
Then, one night in 2007, they bumped into each other on a night out. 
“We ended up going back to the pub, and one thing led to another,” Michelle admitted. Michelle, Kenny and Tyanna on the couple's wedding day (Photo: PA Real Life) 
“I’d no idea he felt the same way about me. He’s a really outgoing person anyway, so it was hard to tell if he was flirting.” 
From there, the couple swapped numbers but, worried about what people would think, kept their romance under wraps at first. 
Eventually, though, Michelle confided in her pals about her older man. 
They were shocked, but supportive, so she soon introduced Kenny to her parents. 
Her dad Geoff is 55, and mum Shirley is 50, meaning Kenny is older than them both. 
Recalling that first meeting, Michelle said: “I felt sick with nerves, but Kenny broke the ice and, within minutes we were chattering away. 
“They all spoke about country and western music, and John Wayne films I’d never heard of.” 
Then, just three months after they became an item, Michelle fell pregnant with Tyanna. 
And on New Year’s Eve 2014, their little family became complete, when Kenny proposed at midnight. 
Now, they’re enjoying married life, and keen to show people that, when it comes to love, age is just a number. 
Despite his advancing years, Michelle said that Kenny doesn’t struggle to keep up with Tyanna, claiming he’s more energetic than most younger dads. 
“People also ask if we worry Kenny won’t get as much time with Tyanna as a younger dad would,” she said. Read More 
“That hurts to hear, but my answer is always the same - nobody knows what’s going to happen in life. 
“The three of us are together now, and that’s all that matters.” 
Michelle added that, when they’re all out together, people assume Kenny is her dad, and Tyanna’s granddad. 
She continued: “The look on people’s faces when we kiss in public is priceless. We always correct them, but just laugh it off. 
“When we first got together, a few people questioned why I was with Kenny and thought it wouldn’t last. But he wasn’t just a flash in the pan – it was serious. 
“To anyone who has a problem with age gap relationships, I’d say get over it because it’s none of your business.” Like us on Facebook
